title: Changing the name of the role won't make it more appealing
body:
making it so that the classic supports {{champion:37}} {{champion:117}} {{champion:43}} {{champion:40}} {{champion:267}} {{champion:16}} don't share half or most of their kits with each other would make support more enjoyable 

if {{champion:37}} actually functioned as a support and not a discount burst mage with {{item:3100}} the people who play(ed) her would probably come back to her

if classic supports weren't actively encouraged to avoid interacting with the enemy unless they can take pot shots with {{item:3303}}, then mage supports would never have become the necessity they are now.

if tank supports actually had good base stats like they used to {{champion:44}} {{champion:12}} {{champion:53}} they might actually be useful in the first half of the game. excluding blitz if he can land hooks.

if supports didn't have 3 items locked into their build every game {{item:2049}} {{item:3107}} {{item:3190}}, they'd probably get picked more. this one is especially grinding to me, because we love to bitch about how stale mage itemization is, how constant ADC builds are, but we can never bring these items up lest we be told off by people who don't play support but insist that there's nothing wrong with this. 

Changing the name of it is just semantics, and people are still going to call it 'support' just like 'marksmen' are still called ADCs despite Riot wanting otherwise. stop beating around the bush; give us a support rework.

I agree get rid of all the silly names

like "wardens" etc just call them all tanks

The point is to give a distinction between more defensive tanks like Galio and Poppy (after early game anyway) and purely offensive ones like Malphite and Sejuani. It's also to finally have a solid class name for champs like Yasuo and Yi. The names for sub-classes is fine, given how "support" **is a role and not a sub-class.**
imo the naming conventions only limit design of individual champs

In my opinion, the introduction of subclasses was great. You say it limits design,  but you forget that a champion doesn't have to fit in just one of these playstyles.

The limitations by this system are natural and self-explanational. You will have a hard time combining assassin and juggernaut in a champion as long as it isn't a form changer like gnar. These contradict each other. But you are able to create a champ who is (for example) a combination of juggernaut and warden.

And the system shows niches we don't have and they can try to fill them.  We got a lot of roaming champs,  but is there a marksman designed for roaming? There was a point that wasn't the case, until Quinns rework. 

That a champion shouldn't have great tankiness, damage and mobility available all the time is common sense. That we label a champ with damage and tankiness but without mobility as juggernaut and a champ without tankiness but with damage and mobility as assassin isn't limiting in itself.

you know how rock paper scissors works? of course you do, but some might not so let me explain


there are 3 choices and each choice is weak against the choice  before it and strong against the choice after it.

like this -  rock --> scissors --> paper --> rock

rock paper scissors is actually not balanced

-----------------

in order to achieve balance there has to be equal forces on both sides otherwise you're not achieving balance. balance would be playing rock paper scissors with just rock to choose

rock=rock

--------

in video games we like to talk about balance a lot, but what everyone actually means is strategic advantage. especially when playing a game that is about taking advantage of your opponents weaknesses.

strategic advantage is something a bit more complex than balance and requires a great number of variables to be enjoyable.


--------

take a game like pokemon for example. if we use their type system we get a couple of different effect cycles that provide simple advantages and then there are effect constants that provide complex advantages.

the basic element type cycle : 

fire --> grass --> water --> fire

----

then there are advanced elements :

ice and electric

these elements do not follow any particular rules, but seems to be designed with the idea that it is the inverse of a basic element such as ice - fire and electric - water.

 ground, rock, and steel

these elements were likely designed as an afterthought for balance with steel not showing up until generation 2.

-----------

and variables like :

flying or not flying

ghost or not ghost

dark or not dark

dragon or not dragon

fairy or not fairy

fighting or not fighting

psychic or not psychic

poison or not poison

bug or not bug

normal or not normal

these variables can stack onto other combinations and have a simple function of negating out as much of the basic elemental damage advantages or in some cases other state variables.

---------------------------

in a game like league of legends though the stats are the elements that make up the strategic balance

currently those stats are all over the place.

each champion is effectively its own variable and with stats being everywhere the game is neither balanced nor does it provide any strategic advantage.


no matter how strategic advantage is implemented in a game like league there needs to be a balance between offense and defense.

currently the scales are shifted towards offense.

changing the name of some champions to warden vs juggernaut doesnt help with balance anymore than calling fire pokemon infernal pokemon. it focuses their kit on a single element of gameplay, but it doesnt fix the offset of defense vs offense nor does it correct strategic advantages that are overbearing.

if we look at all of the strategic elements of league we get something that looks like this

ranged vs melee

offense vs defense

magic vs physical vs true

ability vs basic attacks

cooldown timers vs attack speed

movement vs movement effects

health vs health regeneration

resources vs resource regeneration

critical multiplier vs no critical multiplier

--------------

every item, spell, mastery, rune, and ability in the game is either offensive or defensive and grants one of those variables. it can be a multiplier or an additive constant, but unless the total of the champions kit plus any combination in the game is equal to 0 in terms of value when compared to all other champions then that champion is unbalanced. 

unbalanced champions will be exploited for their positive values and forgotten for their negative values.

this is a matter of mathematical inconsistency and the best way to improve the chances of reaching a balanced point is through simplifying variables before trying to combine them.

---------------

http://www.reactiongifs.com/r/2013/05/didnt-read.gif


**TLDR**


in other words creating more variables by creating more diversity in roles will cause even more imbalance and a feeling of lacking strategic advantage due to that imbalance.
This turned into Pokemon fast

i used pokemon because it's a game that most players playing league either know about or have played and it uses elements which are easy to understand in regards to how one beats the other. had i used another element based game or system it might not have been a easy to relate to or understand.

for example monster hunter, digimon, and final fantasy have similar systems.

I think all the umbrella "class names" are fundamentally bad for the health for the game, just when I thought Riot wasn't capable of doing things worse. Now that they've assigned functions to these classes, it limits design space and balancing to maintain the assigned function -- often to the detriment of the character involved. It doesn't help matters that they continue to insist on pumping out new champions, making the pool so large that it's impossible to avoid making functional copies of other existing champions (or at best, half-copies). This is only made worse from the class identifications, as it encourages every character under that class to have the same sort of tools.

I want champions that were designed for a single function again. Amumu was designed to bandage into a fight, push R, and provide MR reduction/passive damage so his team could finish the fight. Now we get champions with two modes of mobility, a couple defensive steroids, some kind of heavy nuke, and a CC effect because "that's what a Diver needs to function!"

It's too late to turn back now, unfortunately.

>I want champions that were designed for a single function again.

That makes them binary though. They usually become too good at their intended function or not good enough at it to be picked. Options are good, but overly versatile is bad.

Not when those designs can be countered by other picks, items, and said counters can be dealt with by the original champion with their own counter items or teammates.

You know, basically how Dota has functioned for years without imploding in a counter-counter-counter-war.

It's too bad Riot's initial design philosophy of "everyone needs to feel useful, no one can be "countered" by picks/items, and everyone should be able to carry" led to the outcome we've been suffering with since about Season 3 or 4.
I personally beg to differ, as I despise explicit hard counters. I just want to play my champ without being made useless just because someone picked something.

That's the deal, though. Nothing is truly a "hard counter" in the strictest sense, even in Dota. Certain picks are considered counters because of how the hero plays in relation to another, or how one skill directly interferes with a key ability of the one you want to counter. Items can function this way as well, such as Eul's suspending Abaddon during his ult so you avoid healing him with errant damage. Even Slardar and BH's stealth-revealing abilities don't completely ruin heroes that are reliant on the mechanic, as there's ways to remove the debuff in addition to just paying attention to when they're around/the abilities are on cooldown/having allies. Needing to have allies shouldn't be considered a detriment, but in League it has become that way -- everyone wants to be able to handle all situations by themselves, and if they can't, then they consider the situation to be unfair and requires Riot's direct intervention.

The real problem is that Riot decided to side with people like yourself in a game that's trying to be "competitive." League's competitive scene has just been a rotating door of whatever single champion or combination has produced the most oppressive and non-interactive effect, usually by virtue of things being overtuned in a fool's desire to make everyone feel like they're doing something.

>everyone wants to be able to handle all situations by themselves, and if they can't, then they consider the situation to be unfair and requires Riot's direct intervention.

You shouldn't _require_ help to beat something. There shouldn't be a point where I have to say at any stage of the game "can't fight him because he's X". There shouldn't be a game where I lose lane, solely because I got counterpicked. Inversely, I shouldn't be able to pick a champ and _expect to win_ solely because I picked a counter to them.

I'm unfamiliar with Dota's heroes, but I believe there's a  _global silence_ for an ult? That would make it so if I played my main, I couldn't do _anything_ proactive as long as his ult was up. I hear a common match up of a hawk mage against a guy who puts totems down that punish people for casting spells, where the mage is a spell spammer. I'd fucking kill myself in that match up.

Blood Hunter against mobile champions? While it would be hilarious to watch Yasuos kill themselves from Rupture (Hemorrhage?), it would be such a hard counter to mobile champions that I couldn't play the champion I love without making sure he's banned. Which in turn makes them likelier to be picked by the enemy team as a denial pick.
 
But Dota has ways around these like BKB which iirc, gives you complete spell immunity for the duration.

>The real problem is that Riot decided to side with people like yourself in a game that's trying to be "competitive."

You can fuck right off with that "Us versus Them" mentality. Riot has been making problems as quickly as they're fixing them, but I do not believe in using Dota as a model for League. There's always something to be gained in inspiration from similar games, but there is a line to cross. Yes, hard counters would diversify pro play by bringing in champions with specific niches for countering other picks but that'd turn it truly into a game that only cared about the Esports aspect of the game.

Yeah, the "I want to do what I want and nothing should stop me except some perceived 'misplay' on my part" argument.

Oh, and just so you're aware, League/Riot already only cares about the eSport aspect. Any of their claims to the contrary is just to placate the playerbase. I've been playing since before Season 1 and got to watch it devolve into its current state.

Considering I only play League for one champ, yea, I want to be able to play my champ and find reasonable success.

I'm aware of the focus on Esports. I despise it, because I despise Esports in general. But the game isn't entirely revolving around Esports _yet_. Otherwise we'd have a much likelier scenario of your posts where there are 63% win rate champion in low elo but are balanced for pro play.

> Mejai's is supposed to be in here because if Janna herself is not dying but is getting assists, she can easily stack up AP without even investing gold in it. And this in turn, makes her Enchantress nature even more powerful.

Mejai's is a bad buy on Janna. Even if you're ahead, it's so much better to buy redemption, locket, censor, boots, sightstone, almost anything else. Janna isn't meant to be a mage support like Lulu or Sona and build items like Mejai's or Athenes, items like locket, redemption, censor, mikeals, etc are so much better.

Mejai's is an item that is supposed to help champions who want AP but don't have the gold to invest in actual AP items. Buying AP on her isn't terrible. The thing is, you'd only use that AP for more shields/AD or your ult for the heal. Her Q or W aren't that much important, considering that her W can get a bit more slow on the enemy, a bit more MS for you and her Q is mainly used as a disruption tool, not for waveclear or damage. Janna isn't a mage but an Enchanter who scales off AP. There really isn't an AP build for Janna, just these two items that synergize with her kit naturally.

You'd probably go with more AP if the enemy has more single target damage while you'd go for more utility oriented builds if there's more AoE in the enemy team. Even with my proposed Mejai's + Ardent, you wouldn't rush either. You'd first buy a Dark Seal to see if you can keep your stacks at 10 and then you'd normally go for Sightstone and whatever your team needs first. Ardent Censer is probably 4th+ item, to give a bit more stats to champions who already have decent items.

This means it's not delaying your core items at all nor is it replacing them. Redemption and Locket still have room to be built even if Mejai's and Censer are in your inventory.
